lesson_objectives: • In this lesson, you'll learn about the files that are created in a vanilla Hello World project. You will also be introduced to 3 apps that we will write in this unit: Hello Button, Tic Tac Toe (both together in the videos), and LightsOut (the lab)
• In this lesson, you'll learn about making UIs from a specification, including layouts and string and color resources.
• This lesson teaches you how to use button's onClickListeners, and you'll learn how to capture views from the layout, and strings and colors from your resource files.

lesson_title: MVC and Tic Tac Toe Model
lesson_objectives: • This lesson is about the Model-View-Controller design pattern and how Android supports it. We look briefly at a model for a TicTacToe game.
• More practice creating UIs to specification. Introducing TableLayouts.
• In this lesson, you'll learn how to respond when listing to multiple buttons.

• The lab specification is here.
  • If you are taking this course in the academic year, get your lab checked off by an instructor or assistant. If you are taking it in the summer, submit your zipped project plus video demo and complete the Moodle 'Buttons and MVC' self-evaluation survey before calling it a day.

• In this lesson, you'll get an overview of many UI elements: the floating action button, toolbar menu items, snackbars, alert dialogs, and floating context menus. You'll also see a preview of the Point of Sale app that we'll develop together that uses these elements.
• In this lesson, you'll learn about the Floating Action Button
• In this lesson, you'll learn about adding menu items to the toolbar.
• In this lesson, you'll learn how to create snackbars with and without actions, and toast messages.
• In this lesson, you'll learn where to find Android's custom icons and how to create your own. This is important if you post your app on Google Play.
• In this lesson, you'll learn about standard very flexible AlertDialogs, focusing on creating a custom view.
• In this lesson, you'll finish the AlertDialog, focusing on onCreateDialog.
• In this lesson, you'll learn how to show a list of items instead of a message in one of three ways: items only, radio buttons, or checklists.
• In this lesson, you'll practice making dialogs by creating an option to remove all items, asking the user in a dialog to confirm their choice.
• In this lesson, you'll learn how to make floating context menus appear when you long-press on an item.

• The lab specification is here.
  • If you are taking this course in the academic year, get your lab checked off by an instructor or assistant. If you are taking it in the summer, submit your zipped project plus video demo and complete the Moodle 'Menus and Dialogs' self-evaluation survey before calling it a day.
• In this lesson, you'll get an overview of what adapters are and what types of adapters and adapter views are available.
• In this lesson, you'll learn how to create a ListView and populate it using an array and the simplest of ArrayAdapters.
• In this lesson, you'll learn how to override the methods in this abstract class, especially getView().

lesson_title: Modifying a List in an Adapter
lesson_objectives: • In this lesson, we will write methods to add and remove items from the adapter's list of model objects.
• In this lesson, you will learn how to use a RecyclerView and RecyclerAdapter
• In this lesson, you'll learn about some ways to take advantage of RecyclerAdapters: animations, layout managers, and CardViews.

• The lab specification is here.
  • If you are taking this course in the academic year, get your lab checked off by an instructor or assistant. If you are taking it in the summer, submit your zipped project plus video demo and complete the Moodle 'Adapters' self-evaluation survey before calling it a day.
